stream_context.summary: Kaze and guest developer Sauraen spend the entire stream diagnosing why the new F3DEX3 micro-code slows Return to Yoshi’s Island on real N64 hardware. They benchmark old vs. new builds, disable lighting, add custom cycle counters inside the micro-code, and conclude that ~8-9 ms of unexplained RSP time is missing. They agree to build a special “EX 2.5” variant and revisit profiling in a few weeks. Parallel to the tech work, Kaze briefly shows progress on the ‘Calamari Desert’ retro course and discusses level goals.

development_findings.summary: F3DEX3 was designed to cut RDP time and add features (cell-shading, occlusion plane, octahedral normals) but its architectural changes raise RSP time; in RTYI that new bottleneck cancels the gains.
development_findings.quote: I increased features and reduced RDP time, but the cost is that our SP time goes up.

development_findings.summary: Benchmarks show: old EX3 ≈ 25.5 ms, new EX3 ≈ 27 ms, EX2 ≈ 25.5 ms for the GFX task on Kaze’s scene—proving a regression specific to the latest code.
Commenting out all lighting shaved only ~2 ms because ~4,300 of 6,600 vertices are strictly vertex-coloured; lighting overhead alone cannot explain the slowdown.
development_findings.quote: Most of these vertices never even use lighting… maybe 2,300 actually do.

development_findings.summary: RTYI uses up to seven CPU-side directional lights for actors; Kaze purposely avoids point lights so the game stays fast in emulators.
development_findings.quote: Absolutely not using point lights because I want to make sure it runs fine on emulators.

development_findings.summary: Sauraen proposes an ‘EX 2.5’ build: F3DEX3 minus point-light routines, restoring EX2’s faster directional-light path to suit RTYI.
development_findings.quote: I need to make F3DEX 2.5 for Kaze—EX3 with lighting back-ported from EX2.

development_findings.summary: Custom micro-code counters now log pure vertex time (~10 ms) and triangle time (~8 ms); combined they are ≈18 ms, yet total RSP time is ≈27 ms, leaving an 8-9 ms mystery to solve.
Display-list command count per frame is 6–8 k, similar to OOT; command count is not the culprit.
Calamari Desert retro course is being built as a 40-45 s race with train obstacle, vertex-coloured scenery, fake lighting on fires via sheared quads, and future cacti hazards.
Tooling notes: Kaze uses Project64 1.6 for convenience, EverDrive X5 for hardware tests; Sauraen recommends SummerCart64 for quicker USB uploads.

context_findings.summary: Kaze avoids point lights despite liking them, prioritising emulator compatibility over visual richness.
He dislikes spending time on emulator tech, wanting to ‘just make the N64 game’.
context_findings.quote: Ideally I wouldn’t have to deal with emulators at all; I just want to make my N64 game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze worries about disappointing fans but is motivated by community excitement.
context_findings.quote: I hope I don’t disappoint. Everybody’s really pumped about RTYI.

context_findings.summary: Lighthearted attitude toward hacking and tooling; jokes about Project64 malware and crypto-miners.
Brief lament about pirate repro-carts profiting from fan projects, raised by Sauraen; reinforces sensitivity around distribution.

key_stories.title: Chasing Missing Milliseconds
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Sauraen discover that disabling lighting and profiling still leaves ~9 ms of unexplained RSP time, making F3DEX3 slower than expected.
key_stories.challenge: New micro-code increased SP time to 27 ms, negating RDP gains.
key_stories.process: Compared old/new builds, stripped lighting, added cycle counters, inspected command counts.
key_stories.outcome: Identified unexplained overhead; plan to create ‘EX 2.5’ and deeper profiling in next session.
key_stories.key_quote: This would just solve all your problems—there’s an extra eight or nine milliseconds somewhere.

key_stories.title: Lighting Philosophy Pivot
key_stories.summary: Kaze opts for all-vertex-coloured environments and CPU directional lights for actors, rejecting real point lights to stay emulator-friendly.
key_stories.challenge: Point lights cost too much on typical emulators.
key_stories.process: Evaluated micro-code path and visual needs; decided to fake point lights with baked colours.
key_stories.outcome: Levels built around vertex colour; micro-code may be simplified.
key_stories.key_quote: No point lights—absolutely not—because I want to make sure it runs fine on emulators.

key_stories.title: Retro Pipe – Calamari Desert
key_stories.summary: A Mario Kart 64 homage acts as Course 12. Kaze shows its 45-second race concept, explains vertex-colour art, plans a moving train and cactus hazards.
key_stories.challenge: Translating a racing track into a platforming mission while keeping performance in budget.
key_stories.process: Sheared-quad fire, directional sun light, custom textures, planning timers and obstacles.
key_stories.outcome: Visual block-out done; train, timer, and hazards still to implement.
key_stories.key_quote: This area is basically done—we just need the train driving in a circle and the timer.

open_questions.context: Profiling shows vertex+triangle time ≈ 18 ms but total RSP ≈ 27 ms.
questions: What specific micro-code routines consume the missing cycles?
Could DMA stalls, overlay swaps, or cache thrashing be responsible?

open_questions.context: Sauraen suggests a custom build that reinstates EX2 lighting path while keeping EX3 features.
questions: What features will be sacrificed or kept?
How will this variant be maintained long-term?
Will other N64 devs adopt it or is it RTYI-specific?

open_questions.context: Lighting GBI change currently breaks Mario’s vertex colours on stream.
questions: What final lighting pipeline will RTYI use?
How will art and animation teams adapt to GBI changes?
Will baked lighting be automated for artists like Biobak?

open_questions.context: Discussion of unauthorized repro carts profiting from fan games.
questions: How will RTYI be released to minimize piracy yet avoid Nintendo takedowns?
Is the team considering cartridge releases, patches, or free ROMs?
What lessons has Kaze learned from past projects’ piracy?

open_questions.context: Stream focused on tech; little mention of Biobak, Badub, Zeina contributions.
questions: How are graphics, music, and animation pipelines coordinated?
What is Zeina’s day-to-day role and how does marriage affect collaboration?
How does music integration (Badub) interact with micro-code or performance constraints?
